document_title: Orchitis: Causes, signs, diagnosis and prevention
subsection_content:
Typical orchitis symptoms are pain in the testicles and groin area. Usually, testicular pain will start with one testicle and gradually spread to the other testicle. Groin pain and testicular pain are relatively similar, so patients may mistake orchitis for diseases that cause pain in areas other than the groin.
When unusual pain occurs in the groin, it is necessary to observe the health condition of the body, especially the scrotal skin in the testicles. If the patient also has pain in the scrotum, it is a clinical sign of damage to the testicles.
Common symptoms of orchitis that men can recognize:
Scrotal pain; Pain in one or both testicles; The testicles are swollen on one or both sides; Swollen scrotum; painful urination; Pain during ejaculation; Semen mixed with blood; Swollen lymph nodes in the groin area; Some cases have symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, fatigue, fever & chills, and muscle pain
